questions.text: Which principle should a nurse follow to increase stability when transferring a client?
options: Lower the center of gravity.
Face away from the direction of movement.
Use a narrow base of support.
Use only the arms for lifting.

questions.text: What is the primary goal of the Affordable Care Act (ACA)?
options: To decrease the number of clients with private health insurance.
To decrease the number of satisfaction surveys.
To reduce the cost of healthcare by shifting to value-based care.
To reduce the availability of Medicaid coverage.

questions.text: Using Maslow's hierarchy of needs to prioritize safety, which client should the nurse address first?
options: A client asking for a nicotine patch and feeling irritable.
A client who feels lonely and wants more visitors.
A client who is worried about their roommate's alarms.
A client who feels hopeless and is considering suicide.

questions.text: Which statement should the nurse include when teaching a client who is refusing colorectal cancer screening?
options: Screening can detect precancerous polyps.
Screening is only for people with symptoms.
Screening identifies cancer at an advanced stage.
Screening is used to diagnose many types of cancer.

questions.text: A seizure-alert dog for an adolescent with a seizure disorder is an example of which level of prevention?
options: Primary prevention
Quaternary prevention
Primordial prevention
Tertiary prevention

questions.text: What is the most common reason that individuals are uninsured?
options: Insurance is only available for hospitalization services.
Insurance coverage is not affordable.
The client is not eligible for coverage.
The client cannot find a plan that meets their needs.

questions.text: Which example is an internal variable that may influence a person's health?
options: Psychosocial background
Cultural background
Family roles and organization
Client’s perception of the illness

questions.text: Which client presents with a nonmodifiable risk factor?
options: A 48-year-old client who eats a high-fat diet
A 72-year-old male with a sedentary lifestyle
A 22-year-old who binge drinks three nights per week
A 36-year-old client with a family history of diabetes mellitus

questions.text: Which prevention strategy typically occurs at the state level?
options: Tobacco Control Program
Fewer liquor stores in a neighborhood
Anti-smoking campaigns
The Clean Air Act

questions.text: A community program aims to reduce type 2 diabetes through lifestyle changes. Which outcome indicates successful primary prevention?
options: Increased participation in diabetes self-management education
Reduced number of new cases of type 2 diabetes
Decreased hospital admissions for diabetes complications
Improved glycemic control in people with type 2 diabetes

questions.text: A nurse is teaching a new graduate about the Healthy People initiative. Which statements accurately describe Healthy People? Select all that apply.
options: Its goal is to improve the health of the nation.
It addresses health concerns across the lifespan.
It focuses on disease prevention.
It focuses on increasing health disparities.
It addresses health risks and needs of groups.

questions.text: A client has entered the action stage of the Transtheoretical Model for smoking cessation. Which behavior reflects this stage?
options: The client is unaware of the health risks of smoking.
The client has chosen a quit day and is using nicotine replacement therapy.
The client is still weighing the pros and cons of quitting.
The client has been smoke-free for more than six months.

questions.text: A client asks how therapeutic touch works. Which explanation is most accurate?
options: It can be used to promote relaxation and reduce anxiety.
It manipulates bones and joints to release blockages.
It requires essential oils to activate energy centers.
It is only effective when done by massage therapists.

questions.text: A nurse is educating a community group about the mission of Healthy People 2030. Which statement best describes this mission?
options: To reduce healthcare costs.
To promote the health and well-being of all people.
To provide free healthcare for all citizens.
To eliminate all chronic diseases by 2030.

questions.text: A nurse is caring for a client experiencing chronic stress due to work. Which physiological changes are expected? Select all that apply.
options: Increased heart rate
Decreased blood pressure
Enhanced immune response
Elevated blood glucose levels
Decreased sex drive

questions.text: Which complementary therapy is often used to reduce stress and promote relaxation through gentle touch or near-touch?
options: Chiropractic therapy
Therapeutic touch
Herbal medicine
Acupuncture

questions.text: A client with high cholesterol declines prescribed medication and chooses to take garlic instead. This is an example of which type of therapy?
options: Complementary therapy
Alternative therapy
Integrative therapy
Conventional therapy

questions.text: A client under financial stress takes a prescribed medication and also attends free yoga classes in the park. Which type of therapy is this?
options: Alternative therapy
Complementary therapy
Conventional therapy
Holistic therapy

questions.text: A nurse teaches sleep hygiene to a client with insomnia. Which client statement shows effective learning?
options: I will stay in bed even if I cannot sleep.
I will drink chamomile tea before bed.
I should exercise in the evenings.
I will nap during the day to catch up on sleep.

questions.text: A postoperative client is anxious, cannot sleep, and refuses to see their partner. Using Maslow's hierarchy, which need should the nurse prioritize?
options: Anxiety
Refusal to see partner
Inability to sleep
Wound care

questions.text: Which factors contribute to food insecurity in low-income families? Select all that apply.
options: Lack of affordable housing
High medical costs
Stable employment
Chronic health problems
Food allergies

questions.text: A nurse manager asks a new graduate, “What is the nurse’s role in helping clients achieve optimal health?” Which responses are appropriate? Select all that apply.
options: Screen clients for modifiable risk factors at every encounter.
Administer vaccines according to guidelines.
Encourage overweight clients to reduce caloric intake.
Focus only on the client’s presenting concern.
Educate clients on ways to improve health literacy.

questions.text: The nurse develops a care plan to meet a client's basic physiological needs by consulting with social services to assist with food benefits and medication delivery. Which items complete this sentence? Select all that apply.
options: Social services
Food benefits
Medication delivery
Opening a bank account

questions.text: Which nursing action is an example of health promotion?
options: Conducting diagnostic testing
Administering prescribed medication
Performing surgery
Encouraging regular exercise

questions.text: Nurses often work in stressful environments. Which negative impact of stress may occur?
options: Low blood pressure
Increased immune function
Increased depression
Low blood sugar

questions.text: Which is an example of primordial prevention?
options: Improving access to safe walking trails in urban areas
Educating an older adult about healthy eating habits
Developing a checklist for diabetic foot care
Handing out flyers for free mammograms

questions.text: Based on Maslow’s hierarchy, which client should the nurse attend to first?
options: A client anxious about upcoming surgery
A client complaining of severe pain
A client requesting financial assistance information
A client feeling very lonely

questions.text: Which proposal demonstrates a secondary prevention approach for cardiovascular disease?
options: Offering free cholesterol screenings at local clinics
Partnering with schools to provide healthy meals
Launching a campaign to reduce sodium intake
Installing walking and biking trails in the neighborhood

questions.text: An older client with lung disease is admitted with shortness of breath and productive cough and reports not eating all day. Which need should the nurse prioritize?
options: Lack of oxygen
Lack of nutrition
Lack of support
Lack of rest

questions.text: A client has recently lost a loved one and is struggling with faith. Which intervention best supports spiritual wellness?
options: Provide written materials on grief.
Facilitate a visit from the client’s clergy or spiritual advisor.
Assist the client to start an exercise routine.
Encourage the client to join a grief support group.

questions.text: In a community where nutrition is strongly influenced by economics, which resource is most important for the nurse to recommend?
options: Public service announcements on healthy eating
Educational programs on food safety
The Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
The MyPyramid food guidance system

questions.text: Which action is an example of passive health promotion?
options: Following healthy diet guidelines
Following recommended colon cancer screening
Laws mandating seatbelt use in cars
Joining a drug addiction support group

questions.text: A client with newly diagnosed hypertension says, “I know I need to take my medication, but I’m worried about side effects.” Which Health Belief Model component is most evident?
options: Perceived barriers
Perceived financial costs
Perceived severity
Perceived benefits

questions.text: Which observation supports the suspicion that a nurse is experiencing compassion fatigue?
options: Demonstrating excessive empathy
Discussing strong intimate relationships
Difficulty making clinical decisions
Rarely using sick days

questions.text: A nurse encourages clients to achieve higher well-being and self-actualization through lifestyle changes. Which health model is the nurse using?
options: Clinical model
Holistic health model
Health belief model
Health promotion model

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a Healthy People 2030 objective?
options: Promote access to mental health services for underserved populations
Encourage removing mental health services from schools
Decrease availability of crisis hotlines
Discourage mental health screening in older adults

questions.text: A nurse updates meal options for children. Which strategy supports healthy eating habits?
options: Offer larger portions of high-calorie foods.
Incorporate more fruits and vegetables into meals.
Increase the availability of sugary beverages.
Reduce the variety of meal options.

questions.text: A client is experiencing prolonged stress due to chronic illness. According to the General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS), which stage are they likely in?
options: Recovery
Alarm
Exhaustion
Resistance

questions.text: A community program aims to promote a tobacco-free lifestyle among adolescents. Which strategy is most effective?
options: Create local media campaigns to counter tobacco products.
Host events where tobacco companies can advertise.
Ask local markets to reduce the cost of tobacco products.
Allow tobacco promotion in youth community centers.

questions.text: In a discussion on factors that influence health, which belief by staff suggests the need for further education?
options: Genetic makeup influences health.
Mental health issues affect overall health.
Size of home can indirectly influence health.
Health is only influenced by the physical environment.

questions.text: Which Affordable Care Act (ACA) program links reimbursement to clinical outcomes and client satisfaction?
options: Readmission Reduction Program
Hospital-Acquired Condition Reduction Program
Bundled Payments for Care Improvement
Value-Based Purchasing Program

questions.text: A parish nurse helps a client experiencing domestic violence. Based on Maslow’s hierarchy, which action should be prioritized?
options: Secure an apartment in a confidential location.
Arrange for an attorney for legal advice.
Enroll the client in a domestic violence support group.
Purchase clothing items from a thrift store.

questions.text: Which role does the nurse play in advancing global health initiatives?
options: Educating clients only about local issues
Avoiding involvement in policymaking
Collaborating with international organizations
Working only in community hospitals

questions.text: A client is beginning a fitness program to improve health. Which statement should the nurse make?
options: You should do muscle-strengthening activities at least six days a week.
You should alternate moderate and vigorous activity for 50 minutes daily.
You should perform 30 minutes of stretching exercises daily.
You should exercise at a moderate intensity for 150 minutes each week.

questions.text: Which client scenario best represents illness?
options: A client reporting severe abdominal pain
A client with elevated potassium but no symptoms
A client with seasonal allergies controlled by medication
A client recovering from surgery without complications

questions.text: Which scenario is an example of primary prevention?
options: A nurse develops a pamphlet about testicular self-examination.
A client participates in weekly respiratory rehabilitation.
A triage nurse administers oxygen in the emergency room.
An older adult completes routine blood pressure screening.

questions.text: Which of the following is a modifiable health risk?
options: Female gender
Current age
Sedentary lifestyle
Family history

questions.text: A nurse suspects substance use disorder in a client with agitation and seizures. What does this suggest?
options: Agitation and seizures are signs of substance withdrawal.
Agitation and seizures are signs of substance overdose.
Agitation and seizures are signs of chronic pain.
Agitation and seizures are signs of depression.

questions.text: When teaching adolescents about smoking risk, which information should the nurse include?
options: Vaping is a safe alternative to tobacco use.
Parental tobacco use increases adolescent tobacco risk.
Tobacco use usually leads to weight loss.
Most tobacco use begins in early adulthood.

questions.text: Which therapy is an example of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM)?
options: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS)
Acupuncture
Hyperbaric oxygen therapy
Patient-controlled analgesia (PCA)

questions.text: Which client should the nurse prioritize based on Maslow's hierarchy of needs?
options: A client experiencing difficulty breathing
A client anxious about an upcoming surgery
A client feeling lonely and isolated
A client requesting information about a new diet plan

questions.text: Which community health activity is an example of active health promotion?
options: Implementing policy on clean water
Organizing a weekly walking group for seniors
Enforcing a city-wide smoking ban
Encouraging vitamin D-fortified milk intake

questions.text: A nurse is using the holistic health model when caring for a client. Which action best demonstrates this model?
options: Providing printed dietary guidelines for diabetes
Administering pain medication as prescribed
Scheduling a follow-up with the healthcare provider
Encouraging the client to attend a support group for emotional and social needs
